channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Hee-sook Lee, who built an empire with BCD Tofu House chain, dies at 61
item.dc:creator: Brian Park, Lucas Kwan Peterson
item.description: Armed with a secret recipe, her bubbling bowls of soondubu jjigae were all the rage in Koreatown and beyond.
item.content:encoded: Armed with a secret recipe, her bubbling bowls of soondubu jjigae were all the rage in Koreatown and beyond.

media:content.media:description: Lee Hee Sook outside the original BCD Tofu House on Vermont Avenue.

item.title: California lawmakers ask Newsom to act immediately on unemployment claims
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: A majority of the California Legislature calls on Newsom to immediately begin paying unemployment benefits to more than 1 million jobless workers.
item.content:encoded: A majority of the California Legislature calls on Newsom to immediately begin paying unemployment benefits to more than 1 million jobless workers.

media:content.media:description: Joe Marquez, a former sheet metal worker from La Habra, looks for jobs at the One-Stop center in East Los Angeles. The Legislature-approved money will be an immediate lifeline for 76,000 people whose benefits were set to run out April 11.

item.title: Most Apple fire evacuation orders lifted as firefighters gain ground
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Apple fire has charred 27,319 acres and destroyed 12 structures since it was first reported Friday north of Cherry Valley.
item.content:encoded: The Apple fire has charred 27,319 acres and destroyed 12 structures since it was first reported Friday north of Cherry Valley.

media:content.media:description: BANNING, CA - AUGUST 4, 2020: Scorched terrain surrounds a home off Bluff Street as the Apple fire smolders in the background during the coronavirus pandemic on August 4, 2020 in Banning, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'The kids are going stir-crazy': L.A. battles mansion parties that could spread COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Luke Money, Jake Sheridan
item.description: The city attorney's office has said homeowners with a history of renting to partygoers could face criminal prosecution and six months in jail.
item.content:encoded: The city attorney's office has said homeowners with a history of renting to partygoers could face criminal prosecution and six months in jail.

media:content.media:description: Aerial view of a large house party on Mulholland Drive in Beverly Crest, where three people were shot.

item.title: SWAT team helps FBI serve search warrant at Jake Paul's Calabasas mansion
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The FBI has released no information about the search warrant served at Jake Paul's Calabasas mansion except to say that no arrests are planned.
item.content:encoded: The FBI has released no information about the search warrant served at Jake Paul's Calabasas mansion except to say that no arrests are planned.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA - OCTOBER 22: Jake Paul attends Logan Paul Workout Showcase at Wild Card Boxing Club on October 22, 2019 in Hollywood, California.

item.title: The children who need preschool the most are getting the least
item.dc:creator: Sonja Sharp
item.description: As many private preschools prepare to reopen for the school year, many of California's poorest and neediest children are stuck at home, waiting for public preschools to reopen or offer distance learning, which is far from ideal for a 4-year-old.
item.content:encoded: As many private preschools prepare to reopen for the school year, many of California's poorest and neediest children are stuck at home, waiting for public preschools to reopen or offer distance learning, which is far from ideal for a 4-year-old.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 27, 2020 - - Maria Reyes, second from left, spends time with her daughters Marilyn, 9, from left, Darlene, 4, Sophia, 6, and Leilani, 5, right, near their home in Los Angeles on July 27, 2020. All four of the children have attended Head Start, one of three major publicly-funded preschool programs serving low-income California families. California's youngest learners are returning to the classroom. But in the state's neediest zip code, 90011, in where the family lives, preschools remain closed. Such programs are considered essential to closing racial and economic achievement gaps among school-aged children - yet tens of thousands of eligible preschoolers can't get spots, including almost 2,000 Maria's zip code, the state's most underserved. As private preschools across California prepare to reopen, experts fear those in public programs will be left behind, and that thousands of existing spots could disappear. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: What jobs did your parents work to get you where you are today? Readers respond

item.description: What jobs did your parents work to get you where you are today?

item.title: 'I don't know what I'm supposed to do.' Parents in distress over school opening online
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa, Howard Blume
item.description: Reactions ranged from relief to disbelief from some LAUSD parents after the district and United Teachers Los Angeles struck a deal Monday for online learning.
item.content:encoded: Reactions ranged from relief to disbelief from some LAUSD parents after the district and United Teachers Los Angeles struck a deal Monday for online learning.

item.title: Women break silence, tell stories of rape, groping by Ron Jeremy over two decades
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: In the days since Ron Jeremy was charged with sexual assault, half a dozen women have contacted The Times to detail allegations of rape and groping against the adult film star.
item.content:encoded: In the days since Ron Jeremy was charged with sexual assault, half a dozen women have contacted The Times to detail allegations of rape and groping against the adult film star.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Tuesday, June 23, 2020 - Adult film star Ron Jeremy is charged with sexually assaulting four women in Dept. 30 at LA Superior Court. Attorney Stuart Goldfarb is at right. (POOL PHOTO/ Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.description: A magnitude 2.6 earthquake was reported Tuesday evening at 10 p.m. Pacific time two miles from Rancho Cucamonga, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 2.6 earthquake was reported Tuesday evening at 10 p.m. Pacific time two miles from Rancho Cucamonga, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: 30 cases of coronavirus reported at Westlake Food 4 Less; workers demand better protections
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Thirty cases of the novel coronavirus have been reported at a Food 4 Less in Westlake. The union that represents grocery-store workers in Los Angeles has demanded that the business institute better protocols to protect its staff.
item.content:encoded: Thirty cases of the novel coronavirus have been reported at a Food 4 Less in Westlake. The union that represents grocery-store workers in Los Angeles has demanded that the business institute better protocols to protect its staff.

item.title: As summer progresses, social distancing in San Francisco parks proves challenging
item.dc:creator: Chace Beech
item.description: As the weeks pass and the temperatures rise, more residents are flocking to the city's parks.
item.content:encoded: As the weeks pass and the temperatures rise, more residents are flocking to the city's parks.

media:content.media:description: Visitors set up inside circles designed to help prevent the spread of the coronavirus by encouraging social distancing at Dolores Park in San Francisco, Sunday, May 24, 2020. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

item.title: L.A. County voters to decide whether to divert millions to social services and racial justice
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: L.A. County supervisors pass a measure to let voters decide whether to boost funding for mental health, housing and other social programs.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County supervisors pass a measure to let voters decide whether to boost funding for mental health, housing and other social programs.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-JANUARY 29, 2019: LA County Board of Supervisors member Sheila Kuehl listens as Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva speaks in front of LA County Board of Supervisors about his controversial reinstatement of a deputy who had served as his campaign aide and who had been fired in connection with allegations of domestic violence. Supervisors Sheila Kuehl and Kathryn Barger created a motion to challenge the reinstatement and ask county counsel how they can navigate conflicts with the sheriff, including possibly withholding pay from a deputy. (Katie Falkenberg / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ron Deaton, influential advisor to the L.A. City Council, dies at 77
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser
item.description: Deaton ran the DWP for three years and was called the "16th council member" for his role as a behind the scenes player in L.A. city government.
item.content:encoded: Deaton ran the DWP for three years and was called the "16th council member" for his role as a behind the scenes player in L.A. city government.

media:content.media:description: 010164.ME.0612.Parade1.rm Photo shows Ron Deaton, LA City's Chief Legislative Analyst. Photographed in LA City Council Chambers on 5.09.00. (Photo by Rick Meyer/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: No school opening waivers will be considered, L.A. County says, citing high COVID-19 rates
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: The County Department of Public Health, citing high local COVID-19 rates, said it will not grant elementary school reopening waivers until cases drop.
item.content:encoded: The County Department of Public Health, citing high local COVID-19 rates, said it will not grant elementary school reopening waivers until cases drop.

media:content.media:description: MAR VISTA, CA - JULY 13, 2020 - - A sign states, "We miss our Short Avenue Families," at the closed Short Avenue Elementary School in Mar Vista on July 13, 2020. Los Angeles campuses will not reopen for classes on Aug. 18, and the nation's second-largest school system will continue with online learning until further notice, because of the worsening coronavirus surge, Supt. Austin Beutner announced Monday. "Let me be crystal clear," Beutner said in an interview with The Times. "We all know the best place for students to learn is in a school setting." But, he said, "We're going in the wrong direction. And as much as we want to be back at schools and have students back at schools - can't do it until it's safe and appropriate." (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Feds add more charges against Ed Buck, including drug distribution and enticing prostitution
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: Ed Buck, who was indicted last year in connection with the overdose deaths of two Black men in his West Hollywood apartment, now faces four additional charges.
item.content:encoded: Ed Buck, who was indicted last year in connection with the overdose deaths of two Black men in his West Hollywood apartment, now faces four additional charges.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES CA SEPTEMBER 19, 2019 -- Prominent Democratic Party donor Ed Buck appears in court Thursday, September 19, 2019, on state charges of running a drug den in his West Hollywood apartment. Buck may also face federal prosecution for an earlier overdose death in the same residence. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Deputies accused of being in secret societies cost L.A. County taxpayers $55 million, records show
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Los Angeles County has paid out roughly $55 million in settlements since 1990 in civil cases involving allegations that sheriff's deputies belonged to a secret society, records show.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County has paid out roughly $55 million in settlements since 1990 in civil cases involving allegations that sheriff's deputies belonged to a secret society, records show.

media:content.media:description: EAST LOS ANGELES, CA MARCH 7, 2019: Entrance to the parking area of the East Los Angeles Sheriff's station in East Los Angeles, CA March 7, 2019. Several new sheriff's deputies working in East L.A. allege that they were hazed by older deputies belonging to the Banditos, a clique known to harass young Latino officers in East L.A. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Child care has been safe during the pandemic. That could be a good sign for schools

item.content:encoded: Hundreds of thousands of essential workers have kept their kids in child care during the pandemic and, so far, these centers haven't been big disease spreaders.

media:content.media:description: Under the supervision of Danielle Elliott (left), Lyric Gerber (middle) and Rayon Aguilera (right) play during break time at Chase Avenue Elementary School during the Cajon Valley Union School District's Emergency Child Care Program on May 5, 2020 in El Cajon, California. The district is offering free child care to essential workers.

item.title: Couple drove through flames to escape raging wildfire: 'I put the pedal to the floor'
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun, Luke Money
item.description: The Apple fire, at more than 26,000 acres, is burning areas that haven't seen fire in years, providing fuel for explosive growth. As of Monday, it was 5% contained.
item.content:encoded: The Apple fire, at more than 26,000 acres, is burning areas that haven't seen fire in years, providing fuel for explosive growth. As of Monday, it was 5% contained.

media:content.media:description: A shell of a burned car sits along Avenida Miravilla days after the Apple fire rushed through on its way to the nearby San Bernardino National Forest, where it has burned more than 26,000 acres.

item.title: Drug users delivering stillbirths could face murder rap if this California case advances
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The Kings County district attorney is prosecuting a young woman on murder charges after drugs were found in her stillbirth baby. Opponents say the case could create a 'terrifying' precedent.
item.content:encoded: The Kings County district attorney is prosecuting a young woman on murder charges after drugs were found in her stillbirth baby. Opponents say the case could create a 'terrifying' precedent.

media:content.media:description: HANFORD, CALIF. - NOV. 15, 2019 - Jennifer Hernandez shows a picture of her daughter Chelsea Becker on her phone. Jennifer is the mother of a Chelsea Becker, 25, of Hanford, who was arrested Wednesday and is being held at Kings County Jail, with bail set at $5 million. charged with murder after giving birth to a stillborn baby boy with toxic amounts of methamphetamine in his system.

item.title: Coronavirus surge slowing in California, but don't expect a repeat of reopening fever
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee
item.description: Epidemiologists and other public health experts said the only way to prevent more surges is to learn from past failure.
item.content:encoded: Epidemiologists and other public health experts said the only way to prevent more surges is to learn from past failure.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -JULY29: Family nurse practitioner Willie Rios, left, collects nasal swab for COVID-19 test from Araceli Merlos at St. John's Well Child and Family Center on Wednesday, July 29, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Census workers are trying to reach more poor Californians and people of color. But the coronavirus could make the wealthy harder to find
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: The pandemic is hurting census participation rates across socio-economic lines.
item.content:encoded: The pandemic is hurting census participation rates across socio-economic lines.

media:content.media:description: This April 5, 2020, photo shows a 2020 census letter mailed to a U.S. resident in Detroit. The U.S. Census Bureau needs more time to wrap up the once-a-decade count because of the coronavirus, opening the possibility of delays in drawing new legislative districts that could help determine what political party is in power, what laws pass or fail and whether communities of color get a voice in their states. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya)

item.title: Sidewalk superheroes and the rest of the Hollywood Boulevard economy are being devastated by coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: Mascots roam near empty streets. Two businesses permanently shut down. The virus spells trouble for one of L.A.'s most iconic blocks.
item.content:encoded: Mascots roam near empty streets. Two businesses permanently shut down. The virus spells trouble for one of L.A.'s most iconic blocks.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - JULY 28, 2020 - - Street performer Javei Rubio, dressed as Mickey Mouse, looks for customers to pose for photos on a deserted section of Hollywood's Walk of Fame in Hollywood on July 28, 2020. The COVID-19 pandemic has changed the landscape in LA's Hollywood/Highland corridor. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Some California elementary schools could reopen if they meet state waiver rules

item.content:encoded: Under a waiver procedure outlined Monday by state officials, some California schools may be able to reopen with coronavirus protocols in place

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA- APRIL 23, 2020: Wearing masks for protection, Rosie Roth, left, Penelope Roth and Ellie Bristow walk from the Bristow's to the Furbush's for a cooking class during home school in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic on April 21, 2020 in Riverside, California. The Bristow's, Roth's and Furbush's, who are also neighbors, have quarantined together and are home schooling the 8 children amongst them using the parents as teachers. They've named the school "Brothbush Academy" coined from the families' last names.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: California has seen an average of 121 deaths per day over the last two weeks, Newsom says. Still, there are reasons for hope.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 03, 2020 - - California Governor Gavin Newsom is interviewed while visiting the Hot and Cool Cafe in Leimert Park after several days of protest in Los Angeles on June 3, 2020. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Former UCLA gynecologist faces 17 additional felony charges
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: Dr. James M. Heaps, 67, faces a total of 20 felonies related to sex crimes alleged by seven of his former patients at his UCLA Health practice.
item.content:encoded: Dr. James M. Heaps, 67, faces a total of 20 felonies related to sex crimes alleged by seven of his former patients at his UCLA Health practice.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA AUGUST 3, 2020 -Dr. James M. Heaps, a former UCLA gynecologist, was charged Monday August 3, 2020, with 17 additional felonies related to sexual misconduct and abuse alleged by five former patients. Heaps was arrested and charged last June on two felony counts of sexual battery by fraud and one felony count of sexual exploitation of a patient. Those charges were based off two former patients who came forward with allegations of abuse that occurred during medical exams. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. Councilman Jose Huizar enters not guilty plea in City Hall corruption case

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles City Councilman Jose Huizar addresses a news conference at City Hall on November 23, 2011.

item.title: Ventura County trails to remain closed through September amid coronavirus concerns
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Part of Santa Paula Canyon â from the forest boundary to about three miles above the Punch Bowl â will remain off-limits as officials look to stave off potential crowding.

item.title: California unemployment agency workers say internal problems are stalling claims process
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: As California grapples with a deluge of requests for unemployment benefits during the pandemic, government workers tasked with processing claims say they are hampered by outdated technology, bureaucratic red tape and a shortage of trained staff.
item.content:encoded: As California grapples with a deluge of requests for unemployment benefits during the pandemic, government workers tasked with processing claims say they are hampered by outdated technology, bureaucratic red tape and a shortage of trained staff.

media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.description: California may soon pass a law to ban the import of "trophy" animal parts from Africa. Activists are targeting an L.A. hunter whose hunt was captured on video.

Her autopsy remains under a "security hold," which blocks disclosure of her autopsy to the public. Photographed at Atwater Village on Monday, July 27, 2020. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus hospitalizations drop in L.A., Orange counties
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Public health officials said they are hopeful that actions taken over the last few weeks have slowed the spread of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Public health officials said they are hopeful that actions taken over the last few weeks have slowed the spread of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Sun-baked Southern California expected to cool off by Wednesday, according to weather service
item.dc:creator: Adam Elmahrek
item.description: The heatwave that has baked the region is expected to ease on Monday, with relief and a noticeable drop in temperatures by the middle of the week.
item.content:encoded: The heatwave that has baked the region is expected to ease on Monday, with relief and a noticeable drop in temperatures by the middle of the week.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - JULY 32, 2020. An ice cream vendors pushes a cart along the sand at Junipero Beach in Long Beach on a warm Friday afternoon, July 31, 2020. A heat wave is expected to grip Southern California through the weekend, with inland temperatures reaching triple digits. (Luis Sinco/Los Aneles Time)

item.title: 'Everything is over the top': How O.C. hair salons work through the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Andrew Turner

item.content:encoded: After securing a permit from the city, TravisVu the Salon on Warner Avenue opened again for business last week. Three chairs were set outside under the shade of a roof for clients to arrive after having booked appointments.

item.title: Firefighters struggle to control Apple fire in Riverside County as winds pick up
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Laura Newberry
item.description: California's first major wildfire of the year grew to more than 20,000 acres overnight after destroying one home and forcing thousands to evacuate.

item.title: Marines identify 8 servicemen presumed dead after training accident off San Clemente Island
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Carlos Lozano
item.description: The Marines late Sunday released the names of eight U.S. servicemen who went missing during a training exercise off San Clemente Island last week.
item.content:encoded: The Marines late Sunday released the names of eight U.S. servicemen who went missing during a training exercise off San Clemente Island last week.

media:content.media:description: The U.S. flag was lowered to half-staff at Park Semper Fi in San Clemente, Calif., on Friday, July 31, 2020. Officials say a military seafaring assault vehicle with 15 Marines and a Navy sailor aboard sank off the coast of Southern California, leaving one of the Marines dead and eight missing. A Marine Corps spokesman says they were traveling in the amphibious assault vehicle from the shores of San Clemente Island to a Navy ship Thursday evening when they reported that the vehicle was taking on water. (Paul Bersebach/The Orange County Register via AP)

item.title: Earthquake: Magnitude 3.1 quake hits near San Jose

item.title: 'They can't silence us.' Instagram accounts recount racism at L.A.'s elite private schools

item.description: Students and alumni from the L.A.'s most exclusive private high schools have launched Instagram campaigns sharing stories of racism and bias on campus.
item.content:encoded: Students and alumni from the L.A.'s most exclusive private high schools have launched Instagram campaigns sharing stories of racism and bias on campus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 29: Sikkiim Hamilton photographed at her Los Angeles home created the @blackatoakwood instagram account highlighting racism at her Oakwood High School located in North Hollywood where she was once a student. Los Angeles on Wednesday, July 29, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Manhattan Beach was once home to Black beachgoers, but the city ran them out. Now it faces a reckoning
item.dc:creator: Rosanna Xia
item.description: Before Manhattan Beach shut it down, Bruce's Beach was a famous Black-owned beach resort. Now, some want the city to atone for its actions.
item.content:encoded: Before Manhattan Beach shut it down, Bruce's Beach was a famous Black-owned beach resort. Now, some want the city to atone for its actions.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTAN BEACH, CA - JULY 30: Scenes from historic Bruce's Beach at 26th Street and Highland Avenue, in Manhattan Beach, CA, photographed Thursday, July 30, 2020. Some of the land making up Bruce's Beach was purchased by African American couple Willa and Charles Bruce, in 1912, establishing a resort that was open to African Americans. But by the 1920s, racial tensions grew in the beach community and the city condemned the properties. The park was renamed multiple times over the next 80 years and in 2007, was re-named for the Bruce family, responsible for trying to bring change and equality to the city. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A.-area parking spots have become dining areas during the pandemic. Will it last?
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: With coronavirus cases surging and indoor dining banned, cities are letting struggling restaurants use sidewalks, parking spaces and private lots to serve meals.
item.content:encoded: With coronavirus cases surging and indoor dining banned, cities are letting struggling restaurants use sidewalks, parking spaces and private lots to serve meals.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 25: Brandon Astudillo, center and wife Rose Astudillo, of Glendale, dine outdoors at Baracoa Cuban Cafe in Atwater Village on Saturday, July 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Restaurant on-site dining limited to outdoor seating due to Covid-19 restrictions in Southern California. Most of the tables are being set up on wide sidewalk areas, or in parking spaces adjacent to the restaurants. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: George Floyd protests: Black police officers see fight for racial justice through personal lens
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Nicole Santa Cruz
item.description: Black law enforcement leaders say they are uniquely equipped to understand the racism embedded in the criminal justice system, the history of oppression of their community and how that has sowed decades of distrust of the police.

An Anaheim police officer wounded an armed suspect, 20-year-old Alan-Osvaldo Reza Palamino who was wanted, along with another Anaheim man on suspicion of attempted murder, kidnapping, assault with a deadly weapon and brandishing a firearm (Mark Boster/ Los Angeles Times).

media:content.media:description: San Clemente Island, viewed from a shuttle aircraft that regularly flies military and civilian personnel to the U.S. Navy-owned land mass 68 miles from San Diego. The military airstrip is seen at the northern end. The southern end has the only remaining ship-to-shore bombardment range in the U.S. The Navy has supported an extensive ecological restoration of endangered plants and animals on the island. [For the record, July 24, 2013: An earlier version of this caption incorrectly said the military airstrip was at the southern end of the island, and the bombardment range to the north.]

item.title: 'Herstory' is out as California revamps K-12 ethnic studies course guide
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal, Howard Blume
item.description: Officials released on Friday the latest draft of an ethnic studies curriculum, nearly a year after the original version became controversial. The latest iteration retains a primary focus on four racial/ethnic groups but attempts to be more inclusive, while trying to avoid flashpoints related to the Israeli/Palestinian conflict.
item.content:encoded: Officials released on Friday the latest draft of an ethnic studies curriculum, nearly a year after the original version became controversial. The latest iteration retains a primary focus on four racial/ethnic groups but attempts to be more inclusive, while trying to avoid flashpoints related to the Israeli/Palestinian conflict.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - JANUARY 22, 2018 - Anti-racism signs are seen around a classroom as students work on assignments during an ethnic studies class at John O'Connell High School in San Francisco, California on January 22, 2018. (Josh Edelson / For the Times)

item.title: After 250 years, Esselen Tribe regains a piece of its ancestral homeland
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith, Kristi Sturgill
item.description: A $4.5-million land deal, brokered by Portland-based environmental group Western Rivers Conservancy, will transfer a 1,199-acre parcel of wilderness along the Little Sur River to the tribe in the name of conservation and cultural resilience.
item.content:encoded: A $4.5-million land deal, brokered by Portland-based environmental group Western Rivers Conservancy, will transfer a 1,199-acre parcel of wilderness along the Little Sur River to the tribe in the name of conservation and cultural resilience.

media:content.media:description: This undated photo provided by the Western Rivers Conservancy shows lupines on the Adler Ranch in Big Sur on the coast of California south of Monterey. A Native American tribe has reclaimed a small part of ancestral lands on California's Big Sur coast that were lost to Spanish colonial settlement nearly 250 years ago. The Mercury News reports the Esselen Tribe of Monterey County closed escrow on 1,199 acres about 5 miles inland from the ocean that was part of a $4.5 million deal involving the state and the Western Rivers Conservancy. It marks the first restoration of any lands to the tribe. The land encompasses old-growth redwoods, oak woodlands, meadows and endangered steelhead trout. (Doug Steakley/Western Rivers Conservancy via AP)

item.title: 1 Marine dead, 8 troops missing after training accident off Southern California coast
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: An amphibious assault vehicle carrying 15 Marines and one Navy sailor began to take on water during a training exercise, the Marine Corps says.
item.content:encoded: An amphibious assault vehicle carrying 15 Marines and one Navy sailor began to take on water during a training exercise, the Marine Corps says.

media:content.media:description: San Clemente Island, viewed from a shuttle aircraft that regularly flies military and civilian personnel to the U.S. Navy-owned land mass 68 miles from San Diego. The military airstrip is seen at the northern end. The southern end has the only remaining ship-to-shore bombardment range in the U.S. The Navy has supported an extensive ecological restoration of endangered plants and animals on the island. [For the record, July 24, 2013: An earlier version of this caption incorrectly said the military airstrip was at the southern end of the island, and the bombardment range to the north.]

media:content.media:description: WHITTER, CA - JULY 08: Denice Nossett, one of dozens of librarians in the Los Angeles Public library system who have stepped up to do contact tracing work, poses for a portrait at her home on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Whitter, CA. Nossett is a contact tracing team leader. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fears grow that releasing thousands of California prisoners will spread COVID-19 into communities
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Richard Winton, Kim Christensen
item.description: Officials cite missteps by state prisons officials handling recent releases of inmates.
item.content:encoded: Officials cite missteps by state prisons officials handling recent releases of inmates.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -JULY 30, 2020: Roderick Thompson Sr. 35, who was released 9 months early from Avenal State Prison due to the coronavirus outbreak, is photographed outside of Union Station in downtown Los Angeles after arriving there this afternoon on an Amtrak bus. Thompson Sr. had been incarcerated at Avenal State Prison for the past 3 and 1/2 years and was released this morning. He took the train from Hanford to Bakersfield and the bus from Bakersfield to Union Station. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County's tracing team repeatedly failed to detect coronavirus outbreaks at workplaces
item.dc:creator: Melody Petersen
item.description: L.A. County's contact-tracing system has repeatedly failed to alert officials to outbreaks at workplaces, allowing COVID-19 to continue to spread.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County's contact-tracing system has repeatedly failed to alert officials to outbreaks at workplaces, allowing COVID-19 to continue to spread.

media:content.media:description: VERNON, CA -- MAY 29: Workers exit the building at the Smithfield Foods-owned Farmer John plant on Friday, May 29, 2020, in Vernon, CA. Their, 153 of 1,837 employees tested positive for COVID-19 between March and May, Los Angeles County officials said. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: From the staggering toll of the pandemic, a shared story of human kindness emerges
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: The stories of California's coronavirus victims are powerful reminders of the many ways a single life can touch others. "Numbers ain't people," one newspaper obituaries writer said. "You have to put a human face on the suffering."
item.content:encoded: The stories of California's coronavirus victims are powerful reminders of the many ways a single life can touch others. "Numbers ain't people," one newspaper obituaries writer said. "You have to put a human face on the suffering."

media:content.media:description: Wanda DeSelle was among the thousands in California who lost her life to COVID-19

item.title: Coronavirus deaths among L.A. County food processing workers bring dire plea from health officials
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Leila Miller, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: County is examining the deaths of two employees at Mission Foods Corp. in Commerce.
item.content:encoded: County is examining the deaths of two employees at Mission Foods Corp. in Commerce.

media:content.media:description: ONTARIO, CA -JULY24: San Bernardino County Health Department LVN Elizabeth McKinnon explains how to self-swab for COVID-19 test to Glenda Guerra at a coronavirus testing site at Ontario Convention Center. Ontario Convention Center on Friday, July 24, 2020 in Ontario, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: An inmate tested positive for COVID-19. Prison staff housed him with uninfected inmates, he says
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Despite testing positive for COVID-19, Alejandro Cantu, an inmate at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison, said he was placed in a pod â a small, enclosed space where inmates bunk a few feet apart â that houses 11 other men, none of them infected.
item.content:encoded: Despite testing positive for COVID-19, Alejandro Cantu, an inmate at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison, said he was placed in a pod â a small, enclosed space where inmates bunk a few feet apart â that houses 11 other men, none of them infected.

media:content.media:description: Three federal judges have ordered Gov. Jerry Brown to reduce California's prison population by nearly 10,000 inmates. Above, razor wire obstacles sit atop a fence that surrounds Pleasant Valley State Prison in the Central Valley.

item.title: Orange County Register editor killed in alleged street racing crash
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Eugene Harbrecht, 67, was a Santa Ana resident who had worked for the newspaper since 1984. Most recently, he was the national and international news editor for the greater Southern California News Group.
item.content:encoded: Eugene Harbrecht, 67, was a Santa Ana resident who had worked for the newspaper since 1984. Most recently, he was the national and international news editor for the greater Southern California News Group.

media:content.media:description: Orange County Register editor Eugene Harbrecht was killed in a street racing crash on Thursday afternoon.

item.title: La Luz del Mundo church leader faces new rape charges
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: The state's attorney general has filed new charges against the leader of the Mexico-based La Luz del Mundo megachurch, who has been accused of raping children under the guise of his leadership.
item.content:encoded: The state's attorney general has filed new charges against the leader of the Mexico-based La Luz del Mundo megachurch, who has been accused of raping children under the guise of his leadership.

item.title: After this week's heatwave, there's relief in sight for Southern California
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: Temperatures and the marine layer should be back to normal by Tuesday in L.A.
item.content:encoded: Temperatures and the marine layer should be back to normal by Tuesday in L.A.

media:content.media:description: A woman bikes along the Venice Beach Boardwalk on a hot day this summer.

item.title: Feds add bribery and money laundering charges against L.A. Councilman Jose Huizar
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Joel Rubin
item.description: L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar faces additional charges expanding on allegations that Huizar leveraged his power over real estate development for illicit gain.
item.content:encoded: L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar faces additional charges expanding on allegations that Huizar leveraged his power over real estate development for illicit gain.

media:content.media:description: 14th District council member Jose Huizar.

item.title: Hubert and Kalisa, longtime African lion partners at the L.A. Zoo, are euthanized
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: The lions, both 21 years old, were euthanized after age-related health problems began diminishing their quality of life, the L.A. Zoo said.
item.content:encoded: The lions, both 21 years old, were euthanized after age-related health problems began diminishing their quality of life, the L.A. Zoo said.

media:content.media:description: Hubert grooms his longtime companion, Kalisa in March 2018. The 21-year-old African lions were euthanized Thursday July 30, 2020 due to age-related health problems.

item.title: Lawmakers and jobless workers lash out at California's unemployment agency
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California lawmakers dismissed a plan by Gov. Gavin Newsom that would take two months to resolve a backlog of nearly 1 million unemployment benefit claims, warning at a legislative hearing that many jobless people are already struggling to pay for food and rent.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers dismissed a plan by Gov. Gavin Newsom that would take two months to resolve a backlog of nearly 1 million unemployment benefit claims, warning at a legislative hearing that many jobless people are already struggling to pay for food and rent.

media:content.media:description: Job seekers wait in line to speak with recruiters at a career fair in Ontario in September.
